SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Liver resection for metastatic colorectal cancer became established without randomized trials
Proponents of surgical resection point out 5-year survival approaching 50% whilst critics question how much of the apparent effect is due to patient selection
METHOD: A 2006 systematic review of reported outcomes provided the starting point for citation analysis followed by thematic analysis of the texts of the most cited papers
RESULTS: 54 reports from 1988 to 2002 cited 709 unique publications a total of 1714 times
The 15 most cited papers were explored in detail, and showed clear examples of duplicate reporting and overlapping data sets
Textual analysis revealed proposals for a randomized controlled trial, but this was argued to be unethical by others, and no trial was undertaken
CONCLUSIONS: This critical review reveals how the case for this surgery was made, and examines the arguments that influenced acceptance and adoption of this surgery
